title: 107_hr613
content: The "Character Learning and Student Success Act of 2001" (CLASS Act of 2001) grants funds for developing and promoting character education initiatives. Character education in schools aims to improve students' character by teaching ethical values and virtues, promoting a compassionate and responsible society. It involves social, emotional, and ethical development, enhancing self-esteem and reducing the risk of negative behaviors. Character education in schools integrates ethical values and virtues into the curriculum and daily activities to foster the development of core values in students. It aims to increase self-esteem, reduce isolation, and promote responsible behavior. States and local educational agencies are increasingly promoting character education initiatives to provide effective methodologies and professional development opportunities for teachers and schools. The curr_chunk discusses the need for a central source of information on character education initiatives at the federal, state, and local levels to assess effectiveness and advance character education in schools. The Secretary is authorized to make a 5-year grant to an organization with expertise in providing comprehensive information on character education policies, initiatives, and curricula to schools. The organization must have a representative membership and a commitment to promoting quality character education initiatives. The grant recipient must develop initiatives that address core ethical values, emphasize student motivation and behavior, promote schools as caring communities, allow students to practice character lessons, involve families and communities, and focus on leadership, service, and teamwork in character education. The grantee must focus on leadership, service, and teamwork in character education initiatives and evaluate their effectiveness, including impact on disciplinary referrals and teacher expectations. Congress finds that states and local educational agencies have received federal funding for character education initiatives in schools, but there are minimal reporting requirements on their impact. The number of schools implementing character education, the success of these initiatives, and the needs of schools already implementing them are unknown. Efforts should be made to determine the extent and effectiveness of character education in schools. Efforts should be made to determine the extent of character education in schools, its effectiveness, and the use of Federal funds for character education initiatives. The Secretary is authorized to grant a 5-year grant to an organization demonstrating expertise in evaluation, research, understanding of character education approaches, experience in developing initiatives, identifying quality initiatives, and a record of research and practice in character education. The grant recipient must assess schools' character education initiatives, categorize approaches, evaluate funding impact, and measure effectiveness. The grant recipient must assess character education initiatives in schools, categorize approaches, evaluate funding impact, and measure effectiveness. They are required to submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing research progress, results, future information needs, and grant fund usage. Authorization of $700,000 is provided for each fiscal year. Authorization of $700,000 for each fiscal year 2002 through 2006 is provided to carry out character education initiatives in schools. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "eligible organization" as a tax-exempt organization under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code that has submitted a grant application to the Secretary. It also defines "local educational agency" as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "agency" refers to the definition in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. "School" includes elementary and secondary schools as defined in the same Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education.
